name: bursera-simaruba
country-or-region-of-origin: Northeast coast of South America, Central America to Florida
wildlife-value: Attracts birds, butterflies and bees. This tree is the larval host for the dingy purplewing butterfly.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: The flowers are followed by 1/4 to 1/2 inch long, elliptic fruits which mature over the course of a year from olive green to maroon and contain a three-sided, red nutlet.
flower-description: Small creamy white or pale green flowers in spike-like panicles at the ends of the branches in late winter or spring.
leaf-description: The pinnately compound, 6 to 8 inch long leaves are made up of five (occasionally three or seven), oblong to ovate leaflets reaching up to 3 inches long and 1 inch wide with oblique (asymmetrical) bases and pointed tips.
bark-description: Smooth, shiny and reddish brown, and exfoliates in small, thin flakes. The bark produces American elemi, a balsam resin used in varnishes and as a gum arabic substitute.
uses: The wood is soft and light, ideal as veneer, plywood, rustic furniture, match sticks and toothpicks. When dried, it is used as firewood or charcoal. The wood was used to carve carousel horses.
